study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a cost-effective method for producing poly-γ-glutamic acid (γ-PGA) using a novel strain of Bacillus amyloliquefaciens NX-2S via non-food fermentation.
results_summary: The study found that inulin addition upregulated key genes involved in γ-PGA production, and the novel strain produced 6.85±0.22g/L of γ-PGA without exogenous glutamate, which increased to 39.4±0.38g/L with exogenous glutamate. The method demonstrated high productivity (0.43±0.05g/L/h) in batch fermentation.
population_specificity: Microbial fermentation (Bacillus amyloliquefaciens NX-2S)
effective_dosage: Not specified (fermentation yield: 6.85±0.22g/L without glutamate, 39.4±0.38g/L with glutamate)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if cRGDfK peptide-conjugated poly(γ-glutamic acid)-phenylalanine nanoparticles could enhance the therapeutic efficacy of camptothecin against glioblastoma multiforme.
results_summary: The nanoparticles (RCPN) showed dose- and time-dependent cytotoxicity, increased apoptosis, higher reactive oxygen species generation, and inhibited cell migration in U87MG glioblastoma cells compared to native CPT or unconjugated nanoparticles.
population_specificity: U87MG human glioblastoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of PVA-based electrospun hydrogel nanofibers, including PVAPGA, as scaffolds for cell culture and tissue engineering applications.
results_summary: The study found that 3T3 fibroblast cells exhibited similar viability on all electrospun fibers, with cell viability increasing over time. Cell attachment, communication, and ECM production were observed, suggesting PVAPGA nanofibers are suitable for tissue engineering scaffolds.
population_specificity: 3T3 mouse fibroblast cells
study_duration: Observations were made at 1, 3, and 7 days post-seeding

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid (γ-PGA) could mitigate cold stress effects on rape seedlings by enhancing physiological responses and cold resistance mechanisms.
results_summary: γ-PGA reduced malondialdehyde content by 33.4%, increased proline content by 62.5%, and enhanced antioxidant enzyme activities under cold stress. It also improved fresh weight (24.5%) and chlorophyll content (50.9%) in rape seedlings, suggesting mitigation of cold-induced growth inhibition.
population_specificity: Rape seedlings (Brassica napus) grown hydroponically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if immobilizing cross-linked poly-γ-glutamic acid (γ-PGA) on a Co-Cr alloy surface could enhance its bioactivity and induce apatite formation in simulated body fluid.
results_summary: The study found that γ-PGA immobilization made the Co-Cr alloy surface highly hydrophobic and facilitated the formation of a low-crystalline apatite layer when treated with CaCl2 and soaked in simulated body fluid, indicating improved bioactivity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on Co-Cr alloy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of DOX-loaded micelles based on γ-PGA-g-PLLA for improving the solubility and bioavailability of hydrophobic anti-cancer drugs, particularly in tumor therapy.
results_summary: The study found that DOX-loaded γ-PGA-g-PLLA micelles exhibited faster drug release in acidic conditions, which is advantageous for tumor therapy, and cellular uptake was mediated by GGT.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-cancer effects of Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid (PGA), particularly its ability to promote apoptosis in colorectal cancer cells and modulate signaling pathways.
results_summary: PGA inhibited cancer cell proliferation, induced apoptosis (evidenced by DNA fragmentation and PARP/caspase 3 cleavage), reduced expression of cancer-related genes (COX-2 and iNOS), and activated AMPK in HT-29 colorectal cancer cells.
population_specificity: HT-29 human colorectal cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vivo efficacy of ultra-high molecular weight poly-γ-glutamic acid (UHMW γ-PGA) for wound healing.
results_summary: UHMW γ-PGA significantly reduced wound area by day 8 and promoted epidermal regeneration, collagen pigmentation, and blood vessel regeneration by day 16 compared to controls. Increased levels of transforming growth factor-beta and β-catenin were also observed in treated groups.
population_specificity: Animal model (specific species not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of γ-PGA on the treatment of vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN), particularly its impact on cytological regression and HPV viral load reduction.
results_summary: γ-PGA showed cytological regression in 41.7% and 50% of patients at the first and second post-treatment visits, respectively, and an overall HPV load response rate of 66.7% at the first follow-up, though statistical significance was marginal (p = 0.084). The results suggest γ-PGA may be a promising treatment for primary or persistent VAIN.
population_specificity: 12 high-risk HPV-positive patients with biopsy-proven VAIN (VAIN1, VAIN2, or VAIN3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of low molecular weight γ-PGA as an adjuvant for cancer vaccines by assessing its effects on dendritic cell functions and adaptive immunity in a mouse tumor model.
results_summary: γ-PGA enhanced dendritic cell-mediated functions (activation, maturation, antigen uptake, migration, and lymphocyte priming) in a dose-dependent manner, with TLR4 stimulation as a key mechanism. In vivo, γ-PGA significantly boosted both humoral and cell-mediated immunity, inhibited tumor growth, and induced long-lasting immune memory.
population_specificity: Mice (EG7-OVA tumor model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if amphiphilic poly(γ-glutamic acid) (γ-PGA-AAE) nanoparticles could serve as safe and effective adjuvants to control the balance and induction level of cellular and humoral immunities in vaccines.
results_summary: The study found that γ-PGA-AAE nanoparticles could encapsulate antigens like ovalbumin (OVA) and control the type and induction level of immune responses—cellular immunity was dominant when OVA was encapsulated, while humoral immunity was dominant when OVA was mixed with NPs. The results suggest γ-PGA-AAE NPs are promising adjuvants for vaccine design.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical or in vitro/in vivo models, as human data is not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the targeting efficiency and cytotoxicity of a Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid-based drug delivery system (PAMCN) targeting APN/CD13 for antiangiogenic chemotherapy.
results_summary: PAMCN demonstrated enhanced cytotoxicity and targeting efficiency, reducing IC50 values for cisplatin in HUVEC cells and inhibiting tube formation in vitro. In vivo, PAMCN showed no toxicity in KM mice and reduced hepatic and renal toxicity compared to free cisplatin.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC) and KM mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of transferrin-modified γ-PGA-MAL-PLA-DPPE nanoparticles for targeted delivery of paclitaxel to tumor cells.
results_summary: The nanoparticles demonstrated high encapsulation efficiency, pH-dependent drug release, and enhanced cellular uptake in transferrin receptor-overexpressing cancer cells. Tf modification improved the cytotoxic activity of paclitaxel against targeted tumor cells.
population_specificity: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (C666-1) cells and human cervical carcinoma (Hela) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ultra-high molecular weight poly-γ-glutamic acid (UHMW γ-PGA) inhibits 5-alpha reductase activity and promotes hair growth in telogenic mice.
results_summary: UHMW γ-PGA inhibited 5-alpha reductase activity in vitro and promoted hair growth in telogenic C57BL/6 mice, inducing the anagen phase earlier than the control group. The treated group showed hair growth on over 50% of shaved skin, with more hair follicles observed compared to controls.
population_specificity: Telogenic C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic anti-tumor effects of paclitaxel and imiquimod dispersed in Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid (γ-PGA) and its potential to enhance immune response and tumor inhibition.
results_summary: The study found that γ-PGA-stabilized paclitaxel and imiquimod demonstrated significant tumor-killing effects in vitro and in vivo, enhanced dendritic cell proliferation and activation, and induced systemic anti-tumor memory response, leading to 70% survival in treated mice.
population_specificity: Mouse melanoma tumor model (in vivo) and various tumor cell lines (in vitro).
study_duration: More than 6 months (stability testing); tumor growth monitored until day 41.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid (γPGA) into chitosan (CS) complexes could enhance gene transfection efficiency and explore its potential for DNA/siRNA delivery and photodynamic therapy.
results_summary: The study found that γPGA improved the transfection efficiency of CS complexes by reducing electrostatic interactions, enabling effective gene release. It also demonstrated potential for delivering dual PEGylated siRNAs and expressing membrane-targeted KillerRed for photodynamic therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or preclinical models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid (γPGA) could modulate the development of atopic dermatitis (AD) in a Th2-biased immune disease model.
results_summary: Oral administration of γPGA significantly reduced AD development in NC mice by promoting Th1/Th17 cell differentiation, reducing Th2 responses (e.g., serum IgE), and altering allergic reaction components like mast cells and eosinophils. The study suggests γPGA may have therapeutic potential for human AD.
population_specificity: NC/Nga (NC) mice, a model for atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to eliminate the endogenous plasmid in Bacillus amyloliquefaciens LL3 to study its function and impact on γ-PGA production.
results_summary: Plasmid-cured strains showed a 6% increase in γ-PGA production (4.159 g/l vs. 3.918 g/l in control) and improved early-stage cell growth, with no change in molecular weight or sporulation efficiency.
population_specificity: Bacillus amyloliquefaciens LL3 bacterial strain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of green tea extract (GTE) alone versus GTE coadministered with poly-γ-glutamic acid (γ-PGA) on obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) prevention.
results_summary: In db/db mice, GTE+γ-PGA significantly reduced weight gain, body fat, glucose intolerance, fatty liver incidence, and pancreatic islet size compared to controls, while GTE or γ-PGA alone showed no significant effects.
population_specificity: db/db mice (a model for obesity-induced T2DM) and age-matched nondiabetic mice.
effective_dosage: GTE (1%), γ-PGA (0.1%), or GTE+γ-PGA (1%:0.1%) in diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid (γ-PGA) on angiogenesis and inflammation in a mouse model of colitis.
results_summary: γ-PGA significantly reduced weight loss, disease activity index, colon shortening, histopathological injury, blood vessel densities, and expression of VEGF-A and VEGFR2, while also decreasing leukocyte recruitment to the inflamed colon.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice with dextran sulfate sodium (DSS)-induced colitis.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg and 200 mg/kg body weight per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a novel drug delivery system using Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid (gamma-PGA) nanogels for controlled release of the anticancer drug doxorubicin (Dox).
results_summary: The study found that gamma-PGA nanogels effectively loaded and released Dox in a controlled manner, particularly in the presence of reducing agents like glutathione (GSH). The nanogels demonstrated significant cellular uptake and cytotoxic effects in breast cancer cells (MCF-7), dependent on concentration and treatment time.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cells (MCF-7) in vitro.
effective_dosage: Approximately 38.7 µg Dox per mg of gamma-PGA nanogel.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid nanoparticles as an oral drug delivery system for the anticancer drug pixantrone.
results_summary: The study found that Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid formed pH-dependent nanoparticles with pixantrone, demonstrated efficient cellular uptake, and enhanced drug efficacy in vitro. The nanoparticle size could be controlled by adjusting the solution volume ratio of the components.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the co-production of γ-PGA and fibrinolytic enzyme by Bacillus subtilis GXA-28 under sterilized and non-sterilized conditions using cane molasses and monosodium glutamate waste liquor.
results_summary: The study found that optimal conditions (3% total sugar from cane molasses, 2% glutamate from waste liquor, pH 7.0, 45°C) yielded high γ-PGA (103.5 g/kg-substrates) and fibrinolytic activity (986 U/g-substrates) under non-sterilized conditions, with γ-PGA yield being the highest reported in literature.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study using Bacillus subtilis GXA-28 and substrates).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on production conditions, not human dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid (PGA)-coated superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles (SPIONs) as a chelator for removing heavy metals like lead and cadmium from solutions and simulated gastrointestinal fluid.
results_summary: PGA-SPIONs demonstrated rapid and efficient removal of lead and cadmium, with high removal capacities (147.71 mg/g for lead in SGIF and 31.13 mg/g for cadmium in deionized water). The coating improved dispersion and stability, with minimal interference from essential metals or ionic strength, except for reduced cadmium binding in certain conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using metal solutions and simulated gastrointestinal fluid).
effective_dosage: Not specified (batch studies with varying pH and ionic strengths).
study_duration: Not specified (batch studies without explicit duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if linking an agonistic anti-CD40 monoclonal antibody to amphiphilic poly(γ-glutamic acid) nanoparticles (γ-PGA NPs) could enhance immunostimulatory effects while reducing systemic side effects.
results_summary: Anti-CD40-NPs improved CD40 agonist potency, increasing CD80/CD86 upregulation and IL-12 secretion in antigen-presenting cells, while reducing systemic cytokine levels (IL-6, IL-10, IL-12, TNF-α) in a bladder cancer model. The NPs also induced synergistic B-cell proliferation, likely due to enhanced CD40 multimerization.
population_specificity: Bladder cancer model (preclinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of poly-γ-glutamic acid-coated magnetic nanoparticles (PG-M) for removing Pb2+ from water.
results_summary: PG-M effectively removed Pb2+ with an equilibrium adsorption capacity of 93.3 mg/g, optimal at pH 7.0 and 45 min contact time. The presence of humic acid enhanced removal below 5 mg/L but reduced it above this concentration, and PG-M was reusable after desorption with 0.1 mol/L HCl.
population_specificity: Water treatment applications (not human consumption).
effective_dosage: Not specified (adsorption capacity measured as 93.3 mg/g).
study_duration: Not specified (contact time was 45 min for optimal adsorption).
interactions: Reduced Pb2+ removal efficiency with increasing Ca2+ concentration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether coating chitosan/DNA complexes with poly(γ-glutamic acid) (γ-PGA) could enhance cellular uptake and transfection efficiency via a specific γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)-mediated pathway.
results_summary: The study found that γ-PGA coating made the complexes more compact, significantly enhanced their internalization and transfection efficiency, and identified GGT-mediated endocytosis as the uptake mechanism, with the N-terminal γ-glutamyl unit of γ-PGA playing a key role in this interaction.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study, likely cell cultures)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high molecular weight poly-γ-glutamic acid (hm gamma-PGA) on adiposity, lipid metabolism, and cholesterol levels in rats and humans under high-fat diet conditions.
results_summary: The study found that hm gamma-PGA reduced body weight gain, perirenal fat mass, serum total cholesterol, and LDL cholesterol while increasing HDL cholesterol in rats. In humans, it showed a tendency to lower total and LDL cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats and 20 female human subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of γ-PGA on dendritic cells and its potential for treating Th2-mediated allergic asthma.
results_summary: γ-PGA activated dendritic cells via TLR-4, promoting Th1 responses and reducing Th2-mediated allergic asthma symptoms, including airway hyperresponsiveness, inflammation, and IgE levels. These effects were abolished in TLR-4-defective mice.
population_specificity: Wild-type, TLR-2 deficient, and TLR-4-defective mice sensitized and challenged with ovalbumin (OVA).
study_duration: Repeated intranasal administration before and during the challenge period (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid-based block copolymer as a pH-controllable drug carrier for doxorubicin in treating human breast cancer cells (MCF-7/WT).
results_summary: The study found that the copolymer formed nano-sized micelles (90-200 nm) with pH-dependent properties, enhancing drug uptake in cancer cells while minimizing toxicity to healthy tissues. The micelles showed high drug loading efficiency (97.22%) and slow, controlled release of doxorubicin in acidic environments.
population_specificity: Wild type human breast cancer cells (MCF-7/WT).
effective_dosage: Critical micelle concentration range of 62-130 µg/mL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of γ-PGA-Phe nanoparticles for treating retinal diseases by assessing their anti-inflammatory effects and cellular uptake in pathological conditions.
results_summary: The NPs were efficiently taken up by macrophages and microglia, showed prolonged retention, and demonstrated significant anti-inflammatory effects by suppressing TNFα and MCP-1 expression, reducing microglial activation, and protecting retinal ganglion cells and photoreceptors in pathological retinas.
population_specificity: Rats (normal and pathological models of retinal disease)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the eye irritancy potential of gamma-PGA and its effects on corneal wound healing after alkali burns.
results_summary: Gamma-PGA promoted corneal wound healing compared to controls and showed similar efficacy to hyaluronic acid, likely due to anti-inflammatory effects and enhanced cell migration and proliferation.
population_specificity: 30 white rabbits with alkali-burned corneas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and mechanism of Polygala tenuifolia glycoprotein (ZPG) in alleviating Alzheimer's disease (AD) symptoms and its potential clinical application.
results_summary: ZPG significantly improved cognitive deficits, reduced hippocampal pathology, normalized AD-related biomarkers, modulated gut microbiota and lipid metabolism, and exhibited neuroprotective effects in vitro by reducing apoptosis and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Scopolamine hydrobromide-induced AD mice and Aβ25-35-induced PC12 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of Poly-γ-Glutamic Acid (γ-PGA) as a chelating agent for lead-induced intoxication in mice and compare its effectiveness with meso-2,3-dimercaptosuccinic acid.
results_summary: γ-PGA at 200 and 400 mg/kg reduced lead accumulation in the liver, heart, and testis but was less effective in the kidney and spleen. It also reduced oxidative stress markers (TBARs) in the kidney and brain, improved δ-ALAD activity in blood, and lowered GPT and LDH activities in serum. Hematological changes included increased WBCs and HCT at 400 mg/kg, with slight declines in HGB, MCV, MCH, and MCHC.
population_specificity: Lead-intoxicated mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immune response and adjuvant activity of gamma-PGA nanoparticles in murine dendritic cells and their potential as a vaccine adjuvant.
results_summary: Gamma-PGA nanoparticles significantly upregulated proinflammatory chemokines, cytokines, and costimulatory molecules in dendritic cells, similar to LPS but distinct from unparticulate gamma-PGA. Immunization with gamma-PGA NPs carrying OVA induced strong antigen-specific CD8(+) T-cell responses and cytokine production, outperforming traditional adjuvants like aluminum hydroxide and complete Freund's adjuvant.
population_specificity: Murine bone marrow-derived dendritic cells and mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects and mechanisms of Polygala Tenuifolia (PT) combined with Magnolia officinalis (MO) in treating cognitive impairment (CI) via the gut-brain axis.
results_summary: PT, MO, and their combination (PM) alleviated cognitive decline and neuropathological damage in D-gal-induced mice, reduced pro-inflammatory factors, increased antioxidant levels, and improved gut microbiota balance. PM also upregulated tight junction proteins, activated the cAMP pathway, and inhibited NF-κB signaling.
population_specificity: D-gal-induced cognitive impairment mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the PtCYP721A57 gene in Polygala tenuifolia and explore its role in the biosynthesis pathway of triterpenoid saponins, particularly tenuifolin.
results_summary: The study found that PtCYP721A57 expression was highest in the cortex of Polygala tenuifolia, correlating with tenuifolin content. Expression was influenced by hormones (ABA, CHT) and abiotic stress (drought, NaCl), peaking at 48 hours.
population_specificity: Not specified (plant-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the intervention effects of saponin components from Polygala tenuifolia on dementia and explore their potential mechanisms.
results_summary: The saponin components of P. tenuifolia reduced β-amyloid accumulation, exhibited antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, regulated neurotransmitters, improved synaptic function, inhibited neuronal apoptosis, and modulated autophagy, suggesting potential benefits for dementia prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of Polygala tenuifolia polysaccharide (PTP) on Alzheimer's disease (AD) by examining its impact on endogenous metabolites and gut microbiota.
results_summary: PTP improved disruptions in endogenous metabolites and gut microbiota caused by AD, significantly altering 21 metabolites and enriching specific metabolic pathways. It also increased the relative abundance of beneficial gut bacteria, with changes in microbiota closely linked to metabolite shifts.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro model based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of Polygala tenuifolia (PT) combined with Acorus tatarinowii (AT) in treating Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: The combination of PT and AT with conventional drugs improved cognitive and functional outcomes (MMSE, ADL, ADAS-cog) and clinical effectiveness without increasing adverse events compared to conventional drugs alone. However, the quality of evidence was rated as very low to low.
population_specificity: 1,103 AD patients across 16 studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the sleep-enhancing effect and mechanism of Polygala tenuifolia saponins (PTS) using insomnia-induced mice.
results_summary: YZ-I and YZ-II reduced immobility time, prolonged sleep duration, and increased concentrations of neurotransmitters (5-HT, NE) and inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α), suggesting sedative and hypnotic effects via serotonergic, GABAergic, and immune system modulation.
population_specificity: ICR mice with insomnia induced by p-chlorophenylalanine (PCPA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-Alzheimer's disease (AD) activity of the polysaccharide PTPS from Polygala tenuifolia in a mouse model and explore its molecular mechanism.
results_summary: PTPS improved spatial cognitive deficits in AD mice, reduced cellular damage in the hippocampus, maintained cholinergic system balance, and reduced Aβ deposition. The anti-AD effect was linked to activation of ERK pathway-related proteins and enhanced synaptic plasticity.
population_specificity: Senescence-accelerated mouse/prone8 (SAMP8) model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active compounds in Polygala tenuifolia extract (EPT) and investigate its anti-inflammatory mechanism in treating acute lung injury (ALI) via TLR4/NF-κB and NLRP3 signaling pathways.
results_summary: EPT reduced inflammatory factors and lung damage in ALI models, with polygalacic acid identified as a potential active ingredient. The extract demonstrated efficacy in both in vivo and in vitro models by modulating TLR4/NF-κB and NLRP3 pathways.
population_specificity: Rats (in vivo) and THP-1 cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological activity and mechanism of Polygala tenuifolia seed oil (PWSO) in attenuating hepatic lipid accumulation and inflammation in a mouse model of metabolic-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD).
results_summary: PWSO reduced plasma and hepatic levels of total cholesterol (TC) and triglycerides (TG), ameliorated hepatic lipid accumulation, and improved inflammation by reducing IL-6 and TNF-α levels. It inactivated SREBP1 and SREBP2 to attenuate lipogenesis and mitigated inflammatory responses via the NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced MAFLD mouse model.
effective_dosage: 14% PWSO in diet (replacing 14% of lard oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the bioactive components of Polygala Tenuifolia and evaluate its effects on neuroinflammation and cognitive improvement in Alzheimer's disease models.
results_summary: The study found that PTBP-1-3, a polysaccharide from Polygala Tenuifolia, reduced neuroinflammation by inhibiting microglia/astrocyte activation and lowering inflammatory markers (NO, TNF-α, IL-1β). It also improved learning and memory in Alzheimer's disease rats.
population_specificity: Alzheimer's disease rat models and lipopolysaccharide-activated BV2 microglia cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active constituent of Polygala Tenuifolia that promotes hippocampal neurogenesis in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: DISS was found to be the most effective constituent in enhancing neural stem cell proliferation and neuronal differentiation, and it significantly improved cognitive deficits, neuronal injuries, and neurogenesis disorder in APP/PS1 transgenic mice.
population_specificity: Newborn C57BL/6 mice and adult APP/PS1 transgenic mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism by which combining Polygala tenuifolia (PT) with Magnolia officinalis (MO) mitigates PT-induced gastrointestinal motility disorders.
results_summary: PT + MO (1:2) improved gastrointestinal function in mice with PT-induced motility disorders, primarily by regulating metabolites and pathways related to energy, amino acid, and fatty acid metabolism.
population_specificity: Mice with PT-induced gastrointestinal motility disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Polygala Tenuifolia and ambroxol have synergistic effects in the blood and brain, and whether co-administration alters pharmacokinetics.
results_summary: The study found that Polygala Tenuifolia did not significantly alter the pharmacokinetics of ambroxol in rats, suggesting no pharmacokinetic interactions. Ambroxol penetrated the brain effectively, with a blood-to-brain distribution ratio of 30-34%.
population_specificity: Experimental rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of Polygala tenuifolia Willd (APT) on scopolamine-induced learning and memory impairments in mice.
results_summary: APT ameliorated learning and memory impairment in scopolamine-induced mice by regulating cholinergic activity, increasing BDNF and IL-10 levels, reducing IL-1β and AChE levels, and improving oxidative stress markers (SOD, GSH, MDA).
population_specificity: Scopolamine-induced mice (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antidepressant effects of SY (containing Polygala Tenuifolia) in rats with CUMS-induced depressive-like behaviors and explore its mechanism related to hippocampal neurogenesis and the BDNF signaling pathway.
results_summary: SY demonstrated significant antidepressant effects in CUMS-exposed rats, enhancing hippocampal neurogenesis and activating the BDNF signaling pathway. These effects were blocked by the TrkB antagonist K252a, confirming the pathway's role in SY's mechanism.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats (180-200 g)
study_duration: 35 days (CUMS exposure) plus treatment until behavioral tests were completed

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if RP02-1, a polysaccharide from Polygala tenuifolia, could inhibit pancreatic cancer cell growth by inducing apoptosis and suppressing autophagy.
results_summary: RP02-1 inhibited pancreatic cancer cell proliferation, migration, and colony formation, while inducing apoptosis and suppressing autophagy. It showed minimal toxicity in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer cells (AsPC-1 and BxPC-3) and in vivo models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether the aerial part of Polygala tenuifolia could improve learning and memory impairments induced by d-galactose/NaNO2 in mice.
results_summary: The aerial part of Polygala tenuifolia significantly improved learning and memory performance in mice, modulated cholinergic activity, reduced neuroinflammation and oxidative stress, and enhanced brain-derived neurotrophic factor signaling.
population_specificity: Mice with d-galactose/NaNO2-induced learning and memory impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the sedative and hypnotic effects of Polygala Tenuifolia (PT) on aged insomnia rats and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PT improved memory ability, prolonged sleep time, and modulated neurotransmitter levels (increased 5-HT and GABA, decreased Glu) in aged insomnia rats. Transcriptome analysis identified overlapping differentially expressed genes and suggested involvement in GABAergic signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Aged Sprague-Dawley male rats with induced insomnia.
effective_dosage: 0.0875 g/kg (low), 0.175 g/kg (medium), 0.35 g/kg (high), administered via intragastric administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of Polygala tenuifolia root extract (BT-11) in adolescents aged 9 to 19 years.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in adverse reactions between the BT-11 and placebo groups, with all adverse events resolving without special treatment. Serious adverse reactions were unrelated to the test product.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 9 to 19 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential beneficial effects of Tenuifolin (TEN) from Polygala tenuifolia on neuronal apoptosis and memory deficits in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: TEN treatment reversed spatial learning and memory deficits and reduced neuronal apoptosis in hippocampal areas in APP/PS1 transgenic AD mice. It also protected against Aβ25-35-induced apoptosis, loss of mitochondria-membrane potential, and activation of caspases-3 and -9 in SH-SY5Y cells.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 transgenic Alzheimer's disease mice and SH-SY5Y cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticonvulsant and neuroprotective effects of novel compounds derived from Polygala tenuifolia and Acori Tatarinowii, particularly for treating refractory epilepsies.
results_summary: Compounds 68-70 demonstrated strong anticonvulsant activity, low neurotoxicity, and inhibitory effects on LDH enzymes, with 70 also acting as a positive allosteric modulator at GABAA receptors. These compounds showed promise for treating epilepsy, including refractory forms like Dravet syndrome.
population_specificity: Mouse models of epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize oxidosqualene cyclase (OSC) genes in Polygala tenuifolia seedlings induced by methyl jasmonate (MeJA) and assess their roles in triterpenoid biosynthesis.
results_summary: The study identified two full-length OSC genes (PtCAS1 and PtCAS2) in Polygala tenuifolia, which produce cycloartenol in yeast cells. Expression levels of these genes were highest in flowers and roots, and increased after MeJA treatment.
population_specificity: Polygala tenuifolia seedlings (plant-based study, no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Polygala tenuifolia extract (PTE) exhibits anti-obesity effects and how it influences liver gene expression and gut microbiota.
results_summary: PTE inhibited lipid accumulation in adipocytes and reduced obesity-related markers in mice, including body weight, serum triglycerides, and liver steatosis. It also altered lipid metabolism genes, reduced inflammation, and improved gut microbiota balance.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mice and 3T3-L1 adipocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the neuroprotective effects, mechanisms, and gastrointestinal toxicity of senegenin from Polygala Tenuifolia based on literature from the past two decades.
results_summary: The study found that senegenin exhibits pharmacological activities such as anti-oxidation, anti-inflammation, anti-apoptosis, and cognitive enhancement, with potential applications in treating neurodegenerative diseases, depression, and ischemia-reperfusion injury. However, it also highlighted gaps in systematic evidence for its pharmacological effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and isolate lactate dehydrogenase inhibitors from Polygala tenuifolia and evaluate their bioactivity using PC12 cells.
results_summary: Five compounds from Polygala tenuifolia were identified as lactate dehydrogenase inhibitors and isolated with high purity (93.29-97.65%). The study demonstrated that microwave-assisted extraction coupled with countercurrent chromatography is an efficient method for isolating these compounds, and the bioactivity was confirmed using PC12 cells.
population_specificity: In vitro (PC12 cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the structure of PTP (a polysaccharide from Polygala tenuifolia) and investigate its anticancer effects against SKOV3 xenograft tumor growth in mice, including the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PTP suppressed tumor growth in mice by inducing apoptosis and reduced serum VEGF and EGFR levels, as well as decreased transcript and protein levels of EGFR, VEGF, and CD34 in tumor-bearing mice. The study suggests PTP may be a potent chemopreventive agent for advanced ovarian cancer.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with SKOV3 xenograft tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Polygala tenuifolia root extracts could be used to synthesize silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) with antibacterial properties.
results_summary: The study found that Polygala tenuifolia root extracts successfully synthesized AgNPs with strong antibacterial activity, particularly against Escherichia coli, and the method was eco-friendly, cost-effective, and scalable.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on bacterial cultures).
effective_dosage: 70% aqueous ethanol extract (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of Polygala tenuifolia Willd. (PTW) in alleviating stress-exacerbated atopic dermatitis symptoms and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: PTW significantly reduced stress-exacerbated scratching behavior, skin inflammation, and serum markers like histamine and IgE. It also inhibited mast cell degranulation and modulated the PKA/p38 MAPK signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Mice with TMA-induced atopic dermatitis and human mast cell line-1 (HMC-1) cells.
effective_dosage: 250 mg/kg PTW in mice; 500 µg/mL PTW extract in HMC-1 cells.
study_duration: 6-9 days in mice; 30 min pre-treatment in HMC-1 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the differences between Polygala tenuifolia root bark and root using HPLC fingerprint analysis and active component determination.
results_summary: The study found high similarity among 15 batches of Polygala tenuifolia samples, with significant differences in the contents of polygalaxanthone III and 3,6'-disinapoly sucrose between root bark and root. The results suggested that evaluating quality based on a single ingredient is not reasonable.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro analysis of plant samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of pyruvate and its metabolism in abiotic stress tolerance in Arabidopsis thaliana.
results_summary: The study found that pyruvate metabolism genes are regulated under abiotic stress, exogenous pyruvate enhances stress-responsive gene expression, and pyruvate exhibits cytoprotective effects comparable to other antioxidants.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis thaliana (model plant)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the novel application of mitapivat (a PK activator) in treating acquired PK deficiency, particularly in a patient with transfusion-dependent hemolytic anemia.
results_summary: Mitapivat therapy successfully liberated the patient from transfusions and significantly improved symptoms and quality of life, demonstrating its potential efficacy in acquired PK deficiency.
population_specificity: A patient with acquired PK deficiency due to clonal myeloid disorders, resulting in severe hemolytic anemia and transfusion dependence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathogenesis, clinical characteristics, diagnosis, and treatment of Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency (PKD) to improve medical services for clinicians.
results_summary: The study highlights PKD as a rare disorder causing chronic hemolytic anemia and complications like iron overload and cardiopulmonary issues. Treatment involves individualized approaches, including red blood cell transfusions and pyruvate kinase activators.
population_specificity: Patients with Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency (PKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether elevated mitochondrial superoxide reversibly impairs pyruvate oxidation and metabolic flexibility in skeletal muscle.
results_summary: The study found that elevated matrix superoxide reversibly impaired pyruvate-driven respiration, reducing metabolic flexibility. The pyruvate dehydrogenase kinase inhibitor dichloroacetate partially restored pyruvate-driven respiration, while the thiol reductant DTT did not.
population_specificity: Animal model (iSOD2 knockdown and control mice)
